texts.definition: Parts of the presentation of a game that do not fit its diegesis.
markups: <style="Definition">Parts of the presentation of a game that do not fit its diegesis.</style>

Many games present players with a game world in which the gameplay takes place. <style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style> are the parts which are presented to players that do not fit with the game world due to not fitting in the diegesis.

Displaying scores or health in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Computer%20Games">Computer Games</link></style> such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Asteroids">Asteroids</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pac-Man">Pac-Man</link></style>, the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Mortal%20Kombat%20series">Mortal Kombat series</link></style>, and the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tekken%20series">Tekken series</link></style> are examples of <style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style>. The display of players' names above their avatars in games such as <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/World%20of%20Warcraft">World of Warcraft</link></style> are other examples. As a player in the <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Left%204%20Dead%20series">Left 4 Dead series</link></style> or as spectators in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Counter-Strike">Counter-Strike</link></style> one can see the outlines of team members through walls, which is yet another example of <style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style>.

Breaking <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style> is typically not a design goal in itself, but introducing <style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style> is often to provide players with information they need for the sake of the gameplay and only relevant when a game is to have a diegesis (see <style="Link"><link="diegetically-outstanding-features">Diegetically Outstanding Features</link></style> for ways of trying to strongly convey information to players without breaking <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic Consistency</link></style>). Since this information is most often about the game state, <style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style> are often <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style> of some sort. One example of this is letting players know when other players come and go in games with <style="Link"><link="drop-in-drop-out">Drop-In/Drop-Out</link></style> gameplay. Making <style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style> into <style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style> is an example which does not directly tie to the game state but where <style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style> is instead used to be more sure that players will notice them. <style="Link"><link="quick-time-events">Quick Time Events</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="fake-game-overs">Fake Game Overs</link></style> specifically use <style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style> to introduce gameplay or trick players. Communication is a form of information exchange, and a common form of <style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style> in games is the presentation of <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style>.

In games with <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style>, <style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style> can be used to increase <style="Link"><link="player-character-awareness-consistency">Player/Character Awareness Consistency</link></style>, i.e, make what players are aware of regarding the game state or <style="Link"><link="game-worlds">Gam World</link></style> be more similar to what their <style="Link"><link="player-characters">Player Characters</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="avatars">Avatars</link></style> would be aware of.

<style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style> is a <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Diegetic%20Patterns">Diegetic Pattern</link></style> but relates heavily to interfaces.

<style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style> is not only an <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Interface%20Patterns">Interface Pattern</link></style> because the diegesis in a game is part of its interface, but also because it is often caused by interface elements. Examples include <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="god-fingers">God Fingers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="hud-interfaces">HUD Interfaces</link></style> (including some <style="Link"><link="crosshairs">Crosshairs</link></style>), <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventories</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Juicy%20Interfaces">Juicy Interfaces</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Modal%20Windows">Modal Windows</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pie%20Menus">Pie Menus</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Popup%20Screens">Popup Screens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>, and <style="Link"><link="tooltips">Tooltips</link></style>. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Voice-Overs">Voice-Overs</link></style> stands out as a <style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Feature</style> that is audial rather than visual. <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Modifiable%20Game%20Interfaces">Modifiable Game Interfaces</link></style> give players to add <style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style> to their game as they add elements to their interfaces.

While <style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style> are typically considered in relation to <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/:Computer%20Games">Computer Games</link></style> they do occur frequently in <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Board%20Games">Board Games</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Category:Tabletop%20Roleplaying%20Games">Tabletop Roleplaying Games</link></style> when <style="Link"><link="dice">Dice</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Tokens">Tokens</link></style> are used together with <style="Link"><link="game-boards">Game Boards</link></style> or <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Maps">Maps</link></style>.

oth the <style="Link"><link="diegetic-consistency">Diegetic</link></style> and <style="Link"><link="thematic-consistency">Thematic Consistency</link></style> of games. Since <style="CurrentLink">Non-Diegetic Features</style> can be noted by players, in <style="Link"><link="multiplayer-games">Multiplayer Games</link></style> players may discuss these and this can lead to <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style>.

<style="Link"><link="clues">Clues</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="crosshairs">Crosshairs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="fake-game-overs">Fake Game Overs</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="game-state-indicators">Game State Indicators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="geospatial-game-widgets">Geospatial Game Widgets</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="god-fingers">God Fingers</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="hud-interfaces">HUD Interfaces</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="inventories">Inventories</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Juicy%20Interfaces">Juicy Interfaces</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Modal%20Windows">Modal Windows</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Modifiable%20Game%20Interfaces">Modifiable Game Interfaces</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="non-diegetic-communication">Non-Diegetic Communication</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Pie%20Menus">Pie Menus</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Popup%20Screens">Popup Screens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="progress-indicators">Progress Indicators</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="quick-time-events">Quick Time Events</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="secondary-interface-screens">Secondary Interface Screens</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="tooltips">Tooltips</link></style>, <style="Link"><link="http://virt10.itu.chalmers.se/index.php/Voice-Overs">Voice-Overs</link></style>
